source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.3.1 Possessive marking of kinship terms in Sakha
notes: In my corpus of oral narratives, the lexical compound ийэ аҕа ‘parents’ and the term төрөппүтэр (which literally means ‘those who gave birth’) form an exception to the observation that kinship terms referring to the older generation require possessive marking. Uvarovskij uses the expression аҕа ийэ икки [father mother two] ‘father and mother’ (a coordinate noun phrase as compared to the compound occasionally used nowadays) when referring to his parents, marking both terms for possession of 1SG possessor.
sah: Бу сиргэ мин аҕам ийэм икки Эдьигэҥҥэ бара иликтэринэ үчүгэй нучча дьиэтин туттан олорбуттара.
en: In this place my mother and father had built themselves a good Russian house and lived there before they went to Zhigansk. [this place–DAT 1SG father–POSS.1SG mother–POSS.1SG two E.–DAT go–IPF.CVB not.yet–COND.3PL good Russian house–ACC.3SG build–REFL–PF.CVB sit–PSTPT–POSS.3PL]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.3.1 Possessive marking of kinship terms in Sakha
notes: In two instances of my text count the word төрөппүт is used with reference to parents in general, not to any specific person’s parents, and this might be the reason for lack of possessive marking. In two instances of the compound ийэ аҕа it is used by the speaker to refer to herself and her husband.
sah: Онно оттон барыта харчы ол ийэ аҕа өттүттэн.
en: Of course, there as well everything, all the money, came from her parents. [that.OBL–LOC CP all–POSS.3SG money that mother father side–ABL.3SG]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.3.1 Possessive marking of kinship terms in Sakha
notes: As to the Russian copies mama and papa, in my texts these were used very rarely; only four speakers used the term mama, three of whom used it only with possessive marking (6 tokens), while the fourth speaker, a woman who very frequently switched to Russian while telling me her story, used it 14 times. This speaker used it without possessive marking only four out of the 14 times; and one of these unmarked tokens was within a Russian clause. The term papa was used only six times by three speakers, and it was used only once without a possessive marker by the above-mentioned speaker when referring to her step-father.
en: He came and became a papa for us. [that.OBL–LOC come–PF.CVB 1PL.DAT papa become–PST.3SG]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.3.1 Possessive marking of kinship terms in Sakha
notes: The lack of possessive suffixes on descendant-line kinship terms appears to be pragmatic. As explained to me by one consultant, a dominant family member can indicate his/her dominance by omitting the (expected) possessive suffixes on kinship terms. For instance, a woman who was very clearly the head of the family indicated this by frequently not marking the possessor on the terms denoting children and in-laws (101a). Another speaker, who had complained quite bitterly about her grandchildren being so greedy and demanding and exhausting (a very un-characteristic thing for a Sakha to do), also referred to these grandchildren five times out of six without possessive marking, e.g. (101b). Furthermore, the lack of possessive marking appears to indicate a form of emotional distance; thus, when it was mentioned that children died (101c) or suffered (101d) the possessive marking was omitted.
sah: Онтон биир эрэ табахсыт биир күтүөт табах таддар.
en: Of those, only one is a smoker, one son-in-law smokes. [that–ABL one only tobacco–AGNR one son.in.law tobacco pull–PRSPT]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.3.1 Possessive marking of kinship terms in Sakha
notes: The lack of possessive suffixes on descendant-line kinship terms appears to be pragmatic. As explained to me by one consultant, a dominant family member can indicate his/her dominance by omitting the (expected) possessive suffixes on kinship terms. For instance, a woman who was very clearly the head of the family indicated this by frequently not marking the possessor on the terms denoting children and in-laws (101a). Another speaker, who had complained quite bitterly about her grandchildren being so greedy and demanding and exhausting (a very un-characteristic thing for a Sakha to do), also referred to these grandchildren five times out of six without possessive marking, e.g. (101b). Furthermore, the lack of possessive marking appears to indicate a form of emotional distance; thus, when it was mentioned that children died (101c) or suffered (101d) the possessive marking was omitted.
sah: Сиэттэр эмиэ бука бары үөрэхтэнэн эрэлэр.
en: The grandchildren are also all getting an education. [grandchild–PL also completely all studies–VR–REFL–PF.CVB PROG–PRSPT–PL]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.3.1 Possessive marking of kinship terms in Sakha
notes: The lack of possessive suffixes on descendant-line kinship terms appears to be pragmatic. As explained to me by one consultant, a dominant family member can indicate his/her dominance by omitting the (expected) possessive suffixes on kinship terms. For instance, a woman who was very clearly the head of the family indicated this by frequently not marking the possessor on the terms denoting children and in-laws (101a). Another speaker, who had complained quite bitterly about her grandchildren being so greedy and demanding and exhausting (a very un-characteristic thing for a Sakha to do), also referred to these grandchildren five times out of six without possessive marking, e.g. (101b). Furthermore, the lack of possessive marking appears to indicate a form of emotional distance; thus, when it was mentioned that children died (101c) or suffered (101d) the possessive marking was omitted.
en: The children died terribly. [child–PL INTS die–PF.CVB RES–PST–PL]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.3.1 Possessive marking of kinship terms in Sakha
notes: The lack of possessive suffixes on descendant-line kinship terms appears to be pragmatic. As explained to me by one consultant, a dominant family member can indicate his/her dominance by omitting the (expected) possessive suffixes on kinship terms. For instance, a woman who was very clearly the head of the family indicated this by frequently not marking the possessor on the terms denoting children and in-laws (101a). Another speaker, who had complained quite bitterly about her grandchildren being so greedy and demanding and exhausting (a very un-characteristic thing for a Sakha to do), also referred to these grandchildren five times out of six without possessive marking, e.g. (101b). Furthermore, the lack of possessive marking appears to indicate a form of emotional distance; thus, when it was mentioned that children died (101c) or suffered (101d) the possessive marking was omitted.
sah: Сарсыарда оҕолор чыырбырҕаан турдахтарына улахан үөрий.
en: If/when the children stood up chirping in the morning the joy was great.

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.3.1 Possessive marking of kinship terms in Sakha
notes: In other instances, the speaker broke off what he or she had started to say; and in one case, the speaker seemed to be getting confused about which person to use for his narrative: he started off in first singular, switched to first plural, then to second singular, then to third singular, and at the end of it all he said the following (102), where the lack of possessive marking on ti:s might be explained by the general confusion of his narrative.
sah: Онно хампаабат да тиис буоллар ыарыыта бэрт.
en: Even though the teeth weren’t loose, they hurt unbearably. [that.OBL–LOC move–PRSPT.NEG PTL teeth AUX–COND illness–POSS.3SG INTS]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.3.1 Possessive marking of kinship terms in Sakha
notes: In another case, a person telling me his life-story responded to my stuttering a Sakha question whether he still hunted as follows.
en: I used to hunt. [1SG bag/catch–VR–PRSPT bag/catch–VR–PRSPT be–PST–POSS.1SG]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.3.1 Possessive marking of kinship terms in Sakha
notes: In another case, a person telling me his life-story responded to my stuttering a Sakha question whether he still hunted as follows.
en: Not now, (my) eye is bad. [now now non.existence eye bad]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.3.1 Possessive marking of kinship terms in Sakha
notes: In this case, it was arguably my broken attempts at Sakha which elicited a ‘pidgin-like’ simplified response on his side; this is all the more probable, since in his further elaborations he marked харах ‘eye’ for 1SG possessor.
sah: Бу харахпын ынах туоһугар өлөрбүтүм былырыын.
en: I hurt my eye here on a cow’s horn last year. [this eye–ACC.1SG cow horn–DAT.3SG die–CAUS–PSTPT–POSS.1SG last.year]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.3.1 Possessive marking of kinship terms in Sakha
notes: In other instances, the speaker broke off what he or she had started to say; and in one case, the speaker seemed to be getting confused about which person to use for his narrative: he started off in first singular, switched to first plural, then to second singular, then to third singular, and at the end of it all he said the following (102), where the lack of possessive marking on ti:s might be explained by the general confusion of his narrative.
en: …afterwards the bone got squeezed. [afterwards bone squeeze–REFL–PSTPT say–PF.CVB]
